docs.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey C. Barbakow rescued Tenet Healthcare from scandal a decade ago, creating one of the nation's best-performing hospital operators by being able to demand higher prices from public and private insurers. But now, Mr. Barbakow, Tenet's 58-year-old chairman and chief executive, is in danger of losing the trust among investors that he and his management team have so carefully built up over the years. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., faces a series of government inquiries that call up memories of its troubled past. The inquiries are raising concerns about whether Tenet was too aggressive in raising prices and whether its quest for profits threatens its quality of care.

headline.main: Chief Faces Problems Again After Restoring Tenet Once

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare chairman end chief executive Jeffrey C Barbakow is in danger of losing investors' trust because of company's delay in telling them about federal inquiries it faces; he insists he was unaware until late October that so much of Tenet's spectacular earnings growth has been result of special Medicare reimbursements set in motion by aggressive pricing; exceptional payments accounted for 10 percent of Tenet's inpatient Medicare payments, triple national average, and figure is 42 percent for its Redding Medical Center in California, where two doctors are under investigation for allegedly performing unnecessary heart surgery and other invasive procedures; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. ANTHONY MAZZARELLI is not your usual customer at Sandy's, a cramped, kitschy place the size of a small railway car that serves breakfast at all hours on the western fringe of residential Center City Philadelphia. ''I come here every morning, just because,'' Dr. Mazzarelli said, wedged into one of Sandy's back booths. ''Many times, there is a 50-year-old guy and an 80-year-old guy and we just trade stories. This is the kind of place where you find out what people really think.''
docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Anthony Mazzarelli of Camden, NJ, who, among many other activities, is working on dual law and medical degrees and master's degree in bioethics at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School and the University of Pennsylvania; Mazzarelli has been named one of 10 Outstanding Young Americans for 2002 by US Junior Chamber of Commerce; photos (Special Issue: New Jersey at Its Best) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi smiles so often, and so blindingly, that she sometimes leaves the impression she has few other emotional expressions. It is an illusion, of course, and one she has used to great effect in becoming the highest-ranking woman in Congressional history. She smiled last month when she stood up, alone among the House Democratic leadership, and voted against the resolution authorizing President Bush to use military force in Iraq. She smiled as she bitterly jousted with the House majority leader, Dick Armey, in July, ultimately voting against the Homeland Security Department bill that Mr. Armey and the other Republicans pushed through.

headline.main: THE 2002 ELECTION: Woman in the News; Getting Closer to the Top, And Smiling All the Way

docs.abstract: Woman in the News profile of Rep Nancy Pelosi, who is thought to have enough votes to become House Democratic leader, highest-ranking woman in Congressional history; she was born Mar 26, 1940 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Public health agencies have been urging people of all ages to get flu shots this season, and many employers are now offering free vaccinations, in the hopes of reducing employee absenteeism. But a recent survey shows that few people intend to get the shots -- whether free or otherwise. Only about one-third of the 1,017 people questioned last month said they had been or planned to be vaccinated. Twenty-six percent of those forgoing the vaccine said it was not part of their health regimen, 24 percent said they could not fit it into their schedules, and 10 percent said they feared needles. The remainder cited other reasons, including no insurance coverage, or the doctor's office being too far away.
docs.abstract: Many American workers avoid vaccination against influenza despite its low cost, ready availability and fact that as many Americans die annually of flu as of HIV; some employers offer free immunization in hope of minimizing absenteeism (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN someone gets laid off at one of the major insurers here, employees call it ''getting voted off the island,'' a reference to the television show ''Survivor,'' in which competence often has little to do with a contestant's ability to stay on the island. ''They also say, 'They put your torch out,' '' said Timothy T. Gilchrist of Canton, a survivor of layoffs at Aetna, the Cigna Corporation and Value Health.

headline.main: Insurance Employees Learn to Pack Light

docs.abstract: Article on insurance industry in and around Hartford, Conn, which has laid off about 10 percent of its workforce since 1989; local economy continues to struggle but has gradually bgun to diversify; workers are struggling as well, jumping from company to company with each downsizing, commuting to New York, New Jersey and Philadelphia or starting their own businesses; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans say they are planning to use their new control of Congress to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, while offering tax credits to the uninsured and imposing new limits on damages in medical malpractice cases. President Bush, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Trent Lott, the Senate Republican leader, all said health care legislation would have a high priority in the 108th Congress, which convenes in January. Republican candidates for Congress promised to add drug benefits to Medicare, Mr. Bush made a similar promise two years ago and Democrats have vowed to hold Republicans accountable in the 2004 elections.

headline.main: Republicans Plan to Push Through Prescription Drug Coverage for the Elderly

docs.lead_paragraph: The most shocking thing about American politics is how ''shocked'' we are every time the obvious happens. You'd think it would be a no-brainer to call an election in which a popular, barnstorming president is pitted against a leaderless political party whose only coherent message is that the other guys aim to toss the elderly into the street. But almost everyone got it wrong, including the network stars who giddily imagined that deadlock 2000 would repeat itself and Louisiana would become the new Florida, thus allowing them to ruin our Thanksgivings by bloviating from New Orleans for a solid month. History has a way of moving on, even as pundits and politicians alike keep fighting the last war.
docs.abstract: Frank Rich Op-Ed column questions why commentators were surprised that Republicans, led by popular, barnstorming president, triumphed over leaderless Democrats in midterm elections; faults Democrats for failing to develop coherent issues; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Calvin Rogers Jr. has worked in the catering business for nearly 20 years. From running his own catering company to working as a job developer at the Community Culinary Training Center in Harlem, he estimates, he has prepared thousands of dishes. But there is one recipe he serves up daily. ''My recipe for life is to always have hope, no matter what happens,'' he said. With hope -- plus a pinch of persistence and a dollop of charity -- Mr. Rogers made it through a turbulent year.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Recipe for Coping With Life: Always Have Hope

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, through Federation of Protestant Welfare Services, helps man survive turbulent year of family tragedies and financial difficulties; photo (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: In state offices turnover was almost nil in this week's elections. Gov. George E. Pataki and all but three incumbent members of the state legislature won re-election. One of the consequences of New York's immovable political system, which trades budget fairness for political benefits, is the fiscal crisis in New York City and other counties across the state. These deficits are not simply the result of a cyclical (and thus predictable) economic downturn. They stem from decisions made in Albany on tax cuts, public-sector pensions, Medicaid expansion and more, which shift costs to local governments.

headline.main: How the City Pays for State's Sins

docs.abstract: Andrew White Op-Ed article blames decisions made by New York State's politicians that trade budget fairness for politicial benefits for fiscal crisis in New York City and other counties across state; scores state for shifting costs to local government (M)
